intro: Crepis vesicaria subsp. andryaloides, commonly known as the mouse-ear chickweed, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a low-growing annual or biennial herb that typically reaches heights of 5–20 cm. The plant features small, hairy leaves and produces clusters of tiny, white to pale yellow flowers. It thrives in moist, disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and waste areas. The species is characterized by its distinctive seed heads, which are often inflated and resemble small, inflated balloons.
